awd_titl_txt: Type I: NC State Springboard Innovation Hub NSF I-Corps Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This project from North Carolina State University establishes an I-Corps Site at NC State's innovation and commercialization headquarters - the Springboard Innovation Hub. 

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

NC State's I-Corps Site is a University-wide initiative that supports technology commercialization and startup activities across campus by collaborating with all of the University's entrepreneurial groups and initiatives. This Site will allow NC State to support the commercialization of the technologies emerging from its research expenditures by immersing faculty, postdocs and students in the I-Corp curriculum and methodology and to catalog best practices for engaging faculty and students in technology commercialization and entrepreneurship. The support provided through the I-Corps Site allows increased numbers of NC State faculty, postdocs and students to engage in customer discovery and lean startup methodology, seeding multiple future potential technology commercialization and startup opportunities in the process.

The Research Triangle entrepreneurial ecosystem is active and tech-centric. The startup companies emerging from NC State's I-Corps Site will serve to both bolster this ecosystem and benefit from the increased entrepreneurial talent pool and funding available within the region. The Site's activity will also be leveraged to accelerate a culture shift at this University.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the NC State I-Corps Site award were to introduce faculty and students to the I-Corps methodology through establishment of an entrepreneurial training program for university researchers to catalyze a culture shift at the university to encourage cutting edge technology commercialization through entrepreneurship. This training would also increase underserved populations’ participation in technology commercialization and entrepreneurship, support startup development across NC State University’s campus, and bolster the Research Triangle Park (RTP) ecosystem with an increased entrepreneurial talent pool and startup funding in the region.

 

Under the Site award, NC State created a regional I-Corps short course training in 2017 to engage with NC State and NC State-affiliated research teams. The course introduces researchers to customer discovery, value propositions, and the business model canvas, and serves as a pipeline for the National Science Foundation’s I-Corps Teams Program. As of December 2023, 162 teams have received I-Corps training through twenty-one total cohorts at the regional level. NC State also engaged with seven other regional universities to provide training to their research teams, including: the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Duke University, East Carolina University, the University of North Carolina at Greensboro, NC A&T University, the University of North Carolina at Wilmington, and NC Central University.

 

Four supplemental programs were also implemented during the award period and were integrated into the I-Corps Program process to increase support for I-Corps participants. A Graduate Student Fellowship Program was created in 2018 to match well-motivated business students with faculty seeking to participate in I-Corps and a virtual mentorship matching platform was launched in 2021 to more effectively match I-Corps teams with relevant industry mentors among NC State’s 200,000 plus alumni base. The SWEAT Equity Challenge, a program to support software-based teams, was also created in 2019 to accelerate software innovations at NC State and completion of I-Corps was required for participating teams to receive prototype funding. The SWEAT program also enabled improved engagement with departments on campus outside of traditional STEM disciplines that are typically underrepresented in the technology transfer process. Eight new companies were launched by SWEAT Equity participants following completion of the I-Corps Program and seventy-five percent of those companies included female or underrepresented minority founders.

 

Recognizing the importance of federal small business innovative research (SBIR/STTR) funding support to the growth and success of research-based startups, NC State and the four other universities with I-Corps Sites in North Carolina collectively secured grant funding in 2018 from an NC-based entrepreneurial support organization to create the Next Steps Program, an initiative designed to provide funding support to select graduating I-Corps teams participating in regional programming to pursue federal SBIR/STTR funding. The creation of this program was also the catalyst for the creation of NC State’s SparkPlug Program in 2019 with funding support from NC State’s Kenan Institute for Science, Engineering, and Technology (KIETS). SparkPlug was launched to provide funding to NC State startup companies to work with professional grant writers and increase the competitiveness of SBIR/STTR proposals and of the seventeen companies supported by the program, twelve completed NC State’s I-Corps course prior to receiving funding.

 

Since the establishment of the NC State I-Corps Program in 2017, thirty-two new startups were formed following participation in the program and the culture of innovation both at NC State and within the regional university system has expanded to include additional initiatives to support research-based startup founders. Overall, the number of new NC State startups formed based on university-owned intellectual property increased from an average of thirteen at the beginning of the award to seventeen at the award expiration in 2023. Graduate I-Corps teams were awarded twenty-two total SBIR/STTR awards and have secured $62.9 million in follow-on grant and investment funding following completion of NC State’s regional I-Corps training, a testament to the critical importance of customer discovery training to the translation of university research from the campus laboratories to the marketplace.


 

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2023
Modified by: Wade Fulghum
